sen.j: 節会（せちえ）とは、日本の宮廷で節句（祝の日）などに天皇のもとに群臣を集めて行われた公式行事。
sen.e: The term "Sechi-e" means official events which were held at Japanese Imperial Court on the day of Sekku (seasonal festivals) etc. with the attendance of the Emperor and a large number of his subjects.
The term "Sechi-e" means official events held at the Japanese Imperial Court on the day of Sekku (seasonal festivals) etc. with the attendance of the Emperor and a large number of his subjects.
The term "Sechi-e" means official events held at the Japanese Imperial Court on the day of Sekku (seasonal festivals) etc. with the attendance of the Emperor and a large number of his subjects.
Sechi-e were accompanied by banquets.
Sechi-e were accompanied by banquets.
Sechi-e were accompanied by banquets.

sen.j: 奈良時代以前（律令制日本の律令制下）から続いた。
sen.e: The history of Sechi-e dates back to the time before the Nara Period (the time when Japan was under Ritsuryo system).
The history of Sechi-e dates back to the time before the Nara Period (the time when Japan was under the Ritsuryo system).
The history of Sechi-e dates back to the time before the Nara period (the time when Japan was under the Ritsuryo system).
Gantan no sechi-e (a seasonal court banquet, which was held on the first of January)

Hakuba no sechi-e (a seasonal court banquet, which was held on the seventh of January)

Toka no sechi-e (an Imperial Court Ceremony, which was held on the sixteenth of January)
Toka no sechi-e (an Imperial Court Ceremony, held on the sixteenth of January)
Toka no sechi-e (an Imperial Court Ceremony, held on the sixteenth of January)
Joshi no sechi-e (an Imperial Court Ceremony, which was held on the third of March)

Joshi no sechi-e (an Imperial Court Ceremony, held on the third of March)
Tango no sechi-e (an Imperial Court Ceremony, which was held on the fifth of May)
Tango no sechi-e (an Imperial Court Ceremony, held on the fifth of May)

sen.j: 相撲節会（七月七日、のち七月下旬）
sen.e: Sumai no sechi-e (an Imperial ceremony of Sumo wrestling, which was held on the seventh of July or in the latter half of July)
Sumai no sechi-e (an Imperial ceremony of Sumo wrestling, held on the seventh of July or in the latter half of July)
Sumai no sechi-e (an Imperial ceremony of Sumo wrestling, held on the seventh of July or in the latter half of July)
Choyo no sechi-e (an Imperial Court Ceremony, which was held on the ninth of September)
Choyo no sechi-e (an Imperial Court Ceremony, which held on the ninth of September)
Choyo no sechi-e (an Imperial Court Ceremony, which held on the ninth of September)

sen.j: 豊明節会（十一月新嘗祭翌日の辰の日）
sen.e: Toyoakari no sechi-e (a seasonal court banquet, which was held on the day of Dragon, the next day after Niiname-sai festival in November)
Toyoakari no sechi-e (a seasonal court banquet, held on the day of Dragon, the next day after Niiname-sai festival in November)
Toyoakari no sechi-e (a seasonal court banquet, held on the day of Dragon, the next day after Niiname-sai festival in November)
Sekiten (a ceremony to worship Confucius which was held in spring)
Sekiten (a ceremony to worship Confucius held in spring)
Sekiten (a ceremony to worship Confucius held in spring)
Urabon festival (a Festival for the Dead and Buddhist All Soul's Day, around the 15th of July or August, depending on the local customs)
Urabon festival (a Festival for the Dead and Buddhist All Soul's Day, around the fifteenth of July or August, depending on the local customs)
Urabon festival (a Festival for the Dead and Buddhist All Soul's Day, around the fifteenth of July or August, depending on the local customs)

sen.j: 平安時代には、元日、白馬、踏歌、端午、豊明が五節会として、特に重んじられた。
sen.e: Gantan, Hakuba, Toka, Tango and Toyoakari were particulatly emphasized in the Heian Period as Gosechi-e.
Gantan, Hakuba, Toka, Tango, and Toyoakari were particulatly emphasized during the Heian Period as Gosechi-e.
Gantan, Hakuba, Toka, Tango, and Toyoakari were particularly emphasized during the Heian period as Gosechi-e.

sen.j: 江戸時代には、人日（一月七日）、上巳、端午、七夕、重陽を江戸幕府が式日として定め、五節句として重視した。
sen.e: the Edo bakufu designated Jinjitsu (one of the five seasonal festivals in the Edo period, which was held on the seventh of January), Joshi (one of the five seasonal festivals in the Edo period, which was held on the third of March), Tango (one of the five seasonal festivals in the Edo period, which was held on the fifth of May), Tanabata (one of the five seasonal festivals in the Edo period, which was held on the seventh of July) and Choyo (one of the five seasonal festivals in the Edo period, which was held on the ninth of September) as the days of celebration and emphasized them by calling Gosekku.

the Edo bakufu designated Jinjitsu (one of the five seasonal festivals during the Edo period, held on the seventh of January), Joshi (one of the five seasonal festivals during the Edo period, held on the third of March), Tango (one of the five seasonal festivals during the Edo period, held on the fifth of May), Tanabata (one of the five seasonal festivals during the Edo period, held on the seventh of July) and Choyo (one of the five seasonal festivals during the Edo period, held on the ninth of September) as the days of celebration and emphasized them by calling Gosekku.

The Edo bakufu designated Jinjitsu (one of the five seasonal festivals during the Edo period, held on the seventh of January), Joshi (one of the five seasonal festivals during the Edo period, held on the third of March), Tango (one of the five seasonal festivals during the Edo period, held on the fifth of May), Tanabata (one of the five seasonal festivals during the Edo period, held on the seventh of July) and Choyo (one of the five seasonal festivals during the Edo period, held on the ninth of September) as the days of celebration and emphasized them by calling Gosekku.
